quote: The unexamined life is not worth living.
author: Maya Angelou

quote: Whereof one cannot speak, thereof one must be silent.
author: Ludwig Wittgenstein

quote: Entities should not be multiplied unnecessarily.
author: William of Ockham

quote: The life of man (in a state of nature) is solitary, poor, nasty, brutish, and short.
author: Thomas Hobbes

quote: He who thinks great thoughts, often makes great errors.
author: Martin Heidegger

quote: We live in the best of all possible worlds.
author: Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz

quote: What is rational is actual and what is actual is rational.
author: G. W. F. Hegel

quote: God is dead! He remains dead! And we have killed him..
author: Friedrich Nietzsche

quote: There is but one truly serious philosophical problem, and that is suicide.
author: Albert Camus

quote: One cannot step twice in the same river.
author: Heraclitus

quote: The greatest happiness of the greatest number is the foundation of morals and legislation.
author: Jeremy Bentham

quote: Happiness is a choice, and today I choose to be happy.
author: Immanuel Kant

quote: No man's knowledge here can go beyond his experience.
author: John Locke

quote: God is not willing to do everything, and thus take away our free will and that share of glory which belongs to us.
author: Niccolo Machiavelli

quote: Liberty consists in doing what one desires.
author: John Stuart Mill

quote: It is undesirable to believe a proposition when there is no ground whatever for supposing it true.
author: Bertrand Russell

quote: Even while they teach, men learn.
author: Seneca the Younger

quote: True happiness comes from gaining insight and growing into your best possible self. Otherwise all you're having is immediate gratification pleasure, which is fleeting and doesn't grow you as a person.
author: aristotle

quote: The roots of education are bitter, but the fruit is sweet.
author: aristotle

quote: Before you heal the body you must first heal the mind
author: aristotle

quote: The proof that you know something is that you are able to teach it
author: aristotle

quote: Those who are not angry at the things they should be angry at are thought to be fools, and so are those who are not angry in the right way, at the right time, or with the right persons.
author: aristotle

quote: Whatever we learn to do, we learn by actually doing it; men come to be builders, for instance, by building, and harp players by playing the harp. In the same way, by doing just acts we come to be just; by doing self-controlled acts, we come to be self-controlled ; and by doing brave acts, we become brave.
author: aristotle

quote: The greatest thing by far is to be a master of metaphor; it is the one thing that cannot be learned from others; and it is also a sign of genius, since a good metaphor implies an intuitive perception of the similarity of the dissimilar.
author: aristotle

quote: The society that loses its grip on the past is in danger, for it produces men who know nothing but the present, and who are not aware that life had been, and could be, different from what it is.
author: aristotle

quote: The man who is truly good and wise will bear with dignity whatever fortune sends, and will always make the best of his circumstances.
author: aristotle

quote: The greatest of all pleasures is the pleasure of learning.
author: aristotle

quote: Fortune favours the bold.
author: aristotle

quote: You are what you repeatedly do
author: aristotle

quote: The quality of life is determined by its activities.
author: aristotle

quote: You are what you do repeatedly.
author: aristotle

quote: Anyone who has no need of anybody but himself is either a beast or a God.
author: aristotle

quote: Love is composed of a single soul inhabiting two bodies.
author: aristotle

quote: Love well, be loved and do something of value.
author: aristotle

quote: Philosophy begins with wonder.
author: aristotle

quote: Plato is my friend, but truth is a better friend.
author: aristotle

quote: At his best, man is the noblest of all animals; separated from law and justice he is the worst.
author: aristotle

quote: A promise made must be a promise kept.
author: aristotle

quote: It is better for a city to be governed by a good man than by good laws.
author: aristotle

quote: Men become richer not only by increasing their existing wealth but also by decreasing their expenditure.
author: aristotle

quote: Consider pleasures as they depart, not as they come.
author: aristotle

quote: Dignity does not consist in possessing honors, but in deserving them.
author: aristotle

quote: He who sees things grow from the beginning will have the best view of them.
author: aristotle

quote: Happiness is the reward of virtue.
author: aristotle

quote: If you would understand anything, observe its beginning and its development
author: aristotle

quote: A friend is another I.
author: aristotle

quote: He who hath many friends hath none.
author: aristotle

quote: The hand is the tool of tools.
author: aristotle

quote: Good moral character is not something that we can achieve on our own. We need a culture that supports the conditions under which self-love and friendship flourish.
author: aristotle

quote: We give up leisure in order that we may have leisure, just as we go to war in order that we may have peace.
author: aristotle

quote: We must be neither cowardly nor rash but courageous.
author: aristotle

quote: The true nature of anything is what it becomes at its highest.
author: aristotle

quote: To give away money is an easy matter and in any man's power. But to decide to whom to give it and how large and when, and for what purpose and how, is neither in every man's power nor an easy matter.
author: aristotle

quote: A man's happiness consists in the free exercise of his highest faculties.
author: aristotle

quote: For what is the best choice for each individual is the highest it is possible for him to achieve.
author: aristotle

quote: Those who act receive the prizes.
author: aristotle

quote: A man becomes a friend whenever being loved he loves in return.
author: aristotle

quote: Character is that which reveals moral purpose, exposing the class of things a man chooses and avoids.
author: aristotle

quote: Bad men are full of repentance.
author: aristotle

quote: For we do not think that we know a thing until we are acquainted with its primary conditions or first principles, and have carried our analysis as far as its simplest elements.
author: aristotle

quote: Philosophy can make people sick.
author: aristotle

quote: Civil confusions often spring from trifles but decide great issues.
author: aristotle

quote: All men by nature desire knowledge.
author: aristotle

quote: But is it just then that the few and the wealthy should be the rulers? And what if they, in like manner, rob and plunder the people, - is this just?
author: aristotle

quote: Definition of tragedy: A hero destroyed by the excess of his virtues
author: aristotle

quote: Every rascal is not a thief, but every thief is a rascal.
author: aristotle

quote: It is difficult to find happiness within oneself, but it is impossible to find it anywhere else.
author: schopenhauer

quote: A high degree of intellect tends to make a man unsocial.
author: schopenhauer

quote: It is difficult to keep quiet if you have nothing to do
author: schopenhauer

quote: The assumption that animals are without rights, and the illusion that our treatment of them has no moral significance, is a positively outrageous example of Western crudity and barbarity. Universal compassion is the only guarantee of morality.
author: schopenhauer

quote: Every man takes the limits of his own field of vision for the limits of the world.
author: schopenhauer

quote: Thus, the task is not so much to see what no one yet has seen, but to think what nobody yet has thought about that which everybody sees.
author: schopenhauer

quote: Pleasure is never as pleasant as we expected it to be and pain is always more painful. The pain in the world always outweighs the pleasure. If you don't believe it, compare the respective feelings of two animals, one of which is eating the other.
author: schopenhauer

quote: at the death of every friendly soul
author: schopenhauer

quote: arises from the feeling that there is
author: schopenhauer

quote: To be alone is the fate of all great mindsa fate deplored at times, but still always chosen as the less grievous of two evils.
author: schopenhauer

quote: There is not a grain of dust, not an atom that can become nothing, yet man believes that death is the annhilation of his being.
author: schopenhauer

quote: Human life, like all inferior goods, is covered on the outside with a false glitter; what suffers always conceals itself.
author: schopenhauer

quote: The highest, most varied and lasting pleasures are those of the mind.
author: schopenhauer

quote: We seldom speak of what we have but often of what we lack.
author: schopenhauer

quote: Patriotism is the passion of fools and the most foolish of passions.
author: schopenhauer

quote: Truth that is naked is the most beautiful, and the simpler its expression the deeper is the impression it makes.
author: schopenhauer

quote: Restlessness is the hallmark of existence.
author: schopenhauer

quote: Men best show their character in trifles, where they are not on their guard. It is in the simplest habits, that we often see the boundless egotism which pays no regard to the feelings of others and denies nothing to itself.
author: schopenhauer

quote: Whoever wants his judgment to be believed, should express it coolly and dispassionately; for all vehemence springs from the will. And so the judgment might be attributed to the will and not to knowledge, which by its nature is cold.
author: schopenhauer

quote: Our moral virtues benefit mainly other people; intellectual virtues, on the other hand, benefit primarily ourselves; therefore the former make us universally popular, the latter unpopular.
author: schopenhauer

quote: The difficulty is to try and teach the multitude that something can be true and untrue at the same time.
author: schopenhauer

quote: Life to the great majority is only a constant struggle for mere existence, with the certainty of losing it at last.
author: schopenhauer

quote: The effect of music is so very much more powerful and penetrating than is that of the other arts, for these others speak only of the shadow, but music of the essence.
author: schopenhauer

quote: To become indignant at [people's] conduct is as foolish as to be angry with a stone because it rolls into your path. And with many people the wisest thing you can do, is to resolve to make use of those whom you cannot alter.
author: schopenhauer

quote: Necessity is the constant scourge of the lower classes, ennui of the higher ones.
author: schopenhauer

quote: It is most important to allow the brain the full measure of sleep which is required to restore it; for sleep is to a man's whole nature what winding up is to a clock.
author: schopenhauer

quote: It is with trifles, and when he is off guard, that a man best reveals his character.
author: schopenhauer

quote: A man of business will often deceive you without the slightest scruple, but he will absolutely refuse to commit a theft.
author: schopenhauer

quote: The ultimate foundation of honor is the conviction that moral character is unalterable: a single bad action implies that future actions of the same kind will, under similar circumstances, also be bad.
author: schopenhauer

quote: I've never known any trouble than an hour's reading didn't assuage.
author: schopenhauer

quote: What makes people hard-hearted is this, that each man has, or fancies he has, as much as he can bear in his own troubles.
author: schopenhauer

quote: A good supply of resignation is of the first importance in providing for the journey of life.
author: schopenhauer

quote: To desire immortality for the individual is really the same as wanting to perpetuate an error forever.
author: schopenhauer

quote: The cause of laughter is simply the sudden perception of the incongruity between a concept and the real project.
author: schopenhauer

quote: He who can see truly in the midst of general infatuation is like a man whose watch keeps good time, when all clocks in the town in which he lives are wrong. He alone knows the right time; what use is that to him?
author: schopenhauer

quote: If a person is stupid, we excuse him by saying that he cannot help it; but if we attempted to excuse in precisely the same way the person who is bad, we should be laughed at.
author: schopenhauer

quote: My body and my will are one.
author: schopenhauer

quote: In the blessings as well as in the ills of life, less depends upon what befalls us than upon the way in which it is met.
author: schopenhauer

quote: There is no absurdity so palpable but that it may be firmly planted in the human head if you only begin to inculcate it before the age of five, by constantly repeating it with an air of great solemnity.
author: schopenhauer

quote: Thus also every keen pleasure is an error and an illusion, for no attained wish can give lasting satisfaction.
author: schopenhauer

quote: It is a clumsy experiment to make; for it involves the destruction of the very consciousness which puts the question and awaits the answer.
author: schopenhauer

quote: Nothing in nature is by chance... Something appears to be chance only because of our lack of knowledge.
author: spinoza

quote: When a man is prey to his emotions, he is not his own master.
author: spinoza

quote: The more clearly you understand yourself and your emotions, the more you become a lover of what is.
author: spinoza

quote: He who seeks equality between unequals seeks an absurdity.
author: spinoza

quote: Academies that are founded at public expense are instituted not so much to cultivate men's natural abilities as to restrain them.
author: spinoza

quote: Hatred is increased by being reciprocated, and can on the other hand be destroyed by love.
author: spinoza

quote: Big fish eat small fish with as much right as they have power.
author: spinoza

quote: Indulge yourself in pleasures only in so far as they are necessary for the preservation of health.
author: spinoza

quote: [Believers] are but triflers who, when they cannot explain a thing, run back to the will of God; this is, truly, a ridiculous way of expressing ignorance.
author: spinoza

quote: Let unswerving integrity be your watchword.
author: spinoza

quote: I have made a ceaseless effort not to ridicule, not to bewail, not to scorn human actions, but to understand them.
author: spinoza

quote: Sadness diminishes a man's powers
author: spinoza

quote: What everyone wants from life is continuous and genuine happiness.
author: spinoza

quote: Nature is satisfied with little; and if she is, I am also.
author: spinoza

quote: He who loves God cannot endeavor that God should love him in return.
author: spinoza

quote: Everything excellent is as difficult as it is rare.
author: spinoza

quote: Everything in nature is a cause from which there flows some effect.
author: spinoza

quote: Blessed are the weak who think that they are good because they have no claws.
author: spinoza

quote: God is the indwelling and not the transient cause of all things.
author: spinoza

quote: All is One (Nature, God)
author: spinoza

quote: Faith is nothing but obedience and piety.
author: spinoza

quote: The more intelligible a thing is, the more easily it is retained in the memory, and counterwise, the less intelligible it is, the more easily we forget it.
author: spinoza

quote: It is usually the case with most men that their nature is so constituted that they pity those who fare badly and envy those who fare well.
author: spinoza

quote: Fame has also this great drawback, that if we pursue it, we must direct our lives so as to please the fancy of men.
author: spinoza

quote: In the mind there is no absolute or free will.
author: spinoza

quote: None are more taken in by flattery than the proud, who wish to be the first and are not.
author: spinoza

quote: I have tried sedulously not to laugh at the acts of man, nor to lament them, nor to detest them, but to understand them.
author: spinoza

quote: Nothing in the universe is contingent, but all things are conditioned to exist and operate in a particular manner by the necessity of the divine nature.
author: spinoza

quote: If men were born free, they would, so long as they remained free, form no conception of good and evil.
author: spinoza

quote: In so far as the mind sees things in their eternal aspect, it participates in eternity.
author: spinoza

quote: them.
author: spinoza

quote: Many errors, of a truth, consist merely in the application of the wrong names of things.
author: spinoza

quote: .... we are a part of nature as a whole, whose order we follow.
author: spinoza

quote: Men will find that they can ... avoid far more easily the perils which beset them on all sides by united action.
author: spinoza

quote: The order and connection of ideas is the same as the order and connection of things.
author: spinoza

quote: Desire is the essence of a man.
author: spinoza

quote: Love is pleasure accompanied by the idea of an external cause, and hatred pain accompanied by the idea of an external cause.
author: spinoza

quote: He that can carp in the most eloquent or acute manner at the weakness of the human mind is held by his fellows as almost divine.
author: spinoza

quote: Emotion, which is suffering, ceases to be suffering as soon as we form a clear and precise picture of it.
author: spinoza

quote: A man is as much affected pleasurably or painfully by the image of a thing past or future as by the image of a thing present.
author: spinoza

quote: Love or hatred towards a thing, which we conceive to be free, must, other things being similar, be greater than if it were felt towards a thing acting by necessity.
author: spinoza

quote: Only that thing is free which exists by the necessities of its own nature, and is determined in its actions by itself alone.
author: spinoza

quote: We learn from history that we do not learn from history
author: hegel

quote: To be independent of public opinion is the first formal condition of achieving anything great.
author: hegel

quote: To be aware of limitations is already to be beyond them.
author: hegel

quote: What history teaches us is that neither nations nor governments ever learn anything from it.
author: hegel

quote: The valor that struggles is better than the weakness that endures.
author: hegel

quote: The more certain our knowledge the less we know.
author: hegel

quote: In a true tragedy, both parties must be right.
author: hegel

quote: Before the end of Time will be the end of History. Before the end of History will be the end of Art.
author: hegel

quote: The learner always begins by finding fault, but the scholar sees the positive merit in everything.
author: hegel

quote: An idea is always a generalization, and generalization is a property of thinking. To generalize means to think.
author: hegel

quote: Genuine tragedy is a case not of right against wrong but of right against right - two equally justified ethical principles embodied in people of unchangeable will.
author: hegel

quote: America is therefore the land of the future, where, in the ages that lie before us, the burden of the World's History shall reveal itself.
author: hegel

quote: The history of the world is none other than the progress of the , consciousness of freedom.
author: hegel

quote: Beauty is merely the Spiritual making itself known sensuously.
author: hegel

quote: All education is the art of making men ethical (sittlich), of transforming the old Adam into the new Adam.
author: hegel

quote: Impatience asks for the impossible, wants to reach the goal without the means of getting there. The length of the journey has to be borne with, for every moment is necessary.
author: hegel

quote: To make abstractions hold in reality is to destroy reality.
author: hegel

quote: Philosophy is by its nature something esoteric, neither made for the mob nor capable of being prepared for the mob.
author: hegel

quote: We learn from history that man can never learn anything from history.
author: hegel

quote: Freedom is the fundamental character of the will, as weight is of matter... That which is free is the will. Will without freedom is an empty word.
author: hegel

quote: The people are that part of the state that does not know what it wants.
author: hegel

quote: We do not need to be shoemakers to know if our shoes fit, and just as little have we any need to be professionals to acquire knowledge of matters of universal interest.
author: hegel

quote: World history is a court of judgment.
author: hegel

quote: The length of the journey has to be borne with, for every moment is necessary.
author: hegel

quote: The proofs of the existence of God are to such an extent fallen into discredit that they pass for something antiquated, belonging to days gone by.
author: hegel

quote: The Catholics had been in the position of oppressors, and the Protestants of the oppressed
author: hegel

quote: To him who looks upon the world rationally, the world in its turn presents a rational aspect. The relation is mutual.
author: hegel

quote: Propounding peace and love without practical or institutional engagement is delusion, not virtue.
author: hegel

quote: It is easier to discover a deficiency in individuals, in states, and in Providence, than to see their real import and value.
author: hegel

quote: Children are potentially free and their life directly embodies nothing save potential freedom. Consequently they are not things and cannot be the property either of their parents or others.
author: hegel

quote: When liberty is mentioned, we must always be careful to observe whether it is not really the assertion of private interests which is thereby designated.
author: hegel

quote: It is because the method of physics does not satisfy the comprehension that we have to go on further.
author: hegel

quote: Consequently, the sensuous aspect of art is related only to the two theoretical sensesof sight and hearing, while smell, taste, and touch remain excluded.
author: hegel

quote: Once the state has been founded, there can no longer be any heroes. They come on the scene only in uncivilized conditions.
author: hegel

quote: Animals are in possession of themselves; their soul is in possession of their body. But they have no right to their life, because they do not will it.
author: hegel

quote: The State is the Divine idea as it exists on Earth.
author: hegel

quote: The Few assume to be the deputies, but they are often only the despoilers of the Many.
author: hegel

quote: We are what we are because we have been what we have been.
author: freud

quote: From error to error one discovers the entire truth.
author: freud

quote: Two hallmarks of a healthy life are the abilities to love and to work. Each requires imagination.
author: freud

quote: When someone abuses me I can defend myself, but against praise I am defenceless.
author: freud

quote: Not all men are worthy of love.
author: freud

quote: The meager satisfaction that man can extract from reality leaves him starving.
author: freud

quote: It is not attention that the child is seeking, but love.
author: freud

quote: The only unnatural sexual behavior is none at all.
author: freud

quote: A woman should soften but not weaken a man.
author: freud

quote: When a love-relationship is at its height there is no room left for any interest in the environment; a pair of lovers are sufficient to themselves
author: freud

quote: All giving is asking, and all asking is an asking for love.
author: freud

quote: The news that reaches your consciousness is incomplete and often not to be relied on.... Turn your eyes inward, look into your own depths, learn first to know yourself!
author: freud

quote: Perhaps the gods are kind to us, by making life more disagreeable as we grow older. In the end death seems less intolerable than the manifold burdens we carry
author: freud

quote: Anxiety in children is originally nothing other than an expression of the fact they are feeling the loss of the person they love.
author: freud

quote: I cannot think of any need in childhood as strong as the need for a father's protection.
author: freud

quote: The virtuous man contents himself with dreaming that which the wicked man does in actual life.
author: freud

quote: The only shame in masturbation is the shame of not doing it well.
author: freud

quote: Religion originates in the child's and young mankind's fears and need for help. It cannot be otherwise.
author: freud

quote: Whatever fosters the growth of civilization works at the same time against war.
author: freud

quote: The doctor should be opaque to his patients and, like a mirror, should show them nothing but what is shown to him.
author: freud

quote: The first human who hurled an insult instead of a stone was the founder of civilization.
author: freud

quote: In mourning it is the world which has become poor and empty; in melancholia it is the ego itself.
author: freud

quote: Sometimes a cigar is just a cigar.
author: freud

quote: Where questions of religion are concerned, people are guilty of every possible sort of dishonesty and intellectual misdemeanor.
author: freud

quote: When we share - that is poetry in the prose of life.
author: freud

quote: The world is no nursery.
author: freud

quote: At bottom God is nothing more than an exalted father.
author: freud

quote: Analogies, it is true, decide nothing, but they can make one feel more at home.
author: freud

quote: The effect of the consolations of religion may be compared to that of a narcotic.
author: freud

quote: [The child receives impressions like] a photographic exposure that can be developed after any interval of time and transformed into a picture.
author: freud

quote: The dream unites the grossest contradictions, permits impossibilities, sets aside the knowledge that influences us by day, and exposes us as ethically and morally obtuse.
author: freud

quote: Where such men love they have no desire and where they desire they cannot love
author: freud

quote: I do not in the least underestimate bisexuality... I expect it to provide all further enlightenment.
author: freud

quote: To endure life remains, when all is said, the first duty of all living being Illusion can have no value if it makes this more difficult for us.
author: freud

quote: A string of reproaches against other people leads one to suspect the existence of a string of self-reproaches with the same content.
author: freud

quote: Lead us, Heavenly Father, lead us O'er the world's tempestuous sea; Guard us, guide us, keep us, feed us, For we have no help but Thee.
author: freud

quote: Sometimes people don't want to hear the truth because they don't want their illusions destroyed.
author: nietzsche

quote: To live is to suffer, to survive is to find some meaning in the suffering.
author: nietzsche

quote: No price is too high to pay for the privilege of owning yourself.
author: nietzsche

quote: Insanity in individuals is something rare - but in groups, parties, nations and epochs, it is the rule.
author: nietzsche

quote: Everything the State says is a lie, and everything it has it has stolen.
author: nietzsche

quote: The snake which cannot cast its skin has to die. As well the minds which are prevented from changing their opinions; they cease to be mind.
author: nietzsche

quote: Man is the only animal that must be encouraged to live.
author: nietzsche

quote: The secret of reaping the greatest fruitfulness and the greatest enjoyment from life is to live dangerously.
author: nietzsche

quote: It is not a lack of love, but a lack of friendship that makes unhappy marriages.
author: nietzsche

quote: The world is beautiful, but has a disease called man.
author: nietzsche

quote: Solitude makes us tougher towards ourselves and tenderer towards others. In both ways it improves our character.
author: nietzsche

quote: The real question is: How much truth can I stand?
author: nietzsche

quote: The true man wants two things: danger and play. For that reason he wants woman, as the most dangerous plaything.
author: nietzsche

quote: There are no beautiful surfaces without a terrible depth.
author: nietzsche

quote: There is always some madness in love. But there is also always some reason in madness.
author: nietzsche

quote: What is the truth, but a lie agreed upon.
author: nietzsche

quote: You know a moment is important when it is making your mind go numb with beauty.
author: nietzsche

quote: Invisible threads are the strongest ties.
author: nietzsche

quote: He who obeys, does not listen to himself!
author: nietzsche

quote: No journey is too great,
author: nietzsche

quote: In revenge and in love, woman is more barbarous than man.
author: nietzsche

quote: Without music, life would be a mistake.
author: nietzsche

quote: All I need is a sheet of paper and something to write with, and then I can turn the world upside down.
author: nietzsche

quote: Ultimately, it is the desire, not the desired, that we love.
author: nietzsche

quote: What is evil?-Whatever springs from weakness.
author: nietzsche

quote: Beware of spitting against the wind!
author: nietzsche

quote: the voice of beauty speaks softly; it creeps only into the most fully awakened souls
author: nietzsche

quote: Everyone needs a sense of shame, but no one needs to feel ashamed.
author: nietzsche

quote: There exists above the "productive" man a yet higher species.
author: nietzsche

quote: For a tree to become tall it must grow tough roots among the rocks.
author: nietzsche

quote: The man of knowledge must be able not only to love his enemies but also to hate his friends.
author: nietzsche

quote: The growth of wisdom may be gauged exactly by the diminution of ill-temper.
author: nietzsche

quote: Most people are too stupid to act in their own interest
author: nietzsche

quote: The visionary lies to himself, the liar only to others.
author: nietzsche

quote: It is the business of the very few to be independent; it is a privilege of the strong.
author: nietzsche

quote: A moral system valid for all is basically immoral.
author: nietzsche

quote: Shared joys make a friend, not shared sufferings.
author: nietzsche

quote: What makes us heroic?--Confronting simultaneously our supreme suffering and our supreme hope.
author: nietzsche

quote: He who asks a question is a fool for a minute; he who does not remains a fool forever.
author: sartre

quote: I can always choose, but I ought to know that if I do not choose, I
author: sartre

quote: am still choosing.
author: sartre

quote: I hate victims who respect their executioners.
author: sartre

quote: Everything has been figured out, except how to live.
author: sartre

quote: your judgement judges you and defines you
author: sartre

quote: slipped out of the world, somewhere else like the soul of a dead man. Perhaps he was only a dream...God is dead.
author: sartre

quote: Nothingness haunts Being.
author: sartre

quote: To choose not to choose is still to act.
author: sartre

quote: Death is a continuation of my life without me.
author: sartre

quote: In a word, man must create his own essence: it is in throwing himself into the world, suffering there, struggling there, that he gradually defines himself.
author: sartre

quote: Imagination is not an empirical or superadded power of consciousness, it is the whole of consciousness as it realizes its freedom.
author: sartre

quote: I am no longer sure of anything. If I satiate my desires, I sin but I deliver myself from them; if I refuse to satisfy them, they infect the whole soul.
author: sartre

quote: To believe is to know you believe, and to know you believe is not to believe.
author: sartre

quote: The more one is absorbed in fighting evil, the less one is tempted to place the good in question.
author: sartre

quote: My thought is me: that's why I can't stop. I exist because I think
author: sartre

quote: Acting is a question of absorbing other people's personalities and adding some of your own experience.
author: sartre

quote: She believed in nothing; only her skepticism kept her from being an atheist.
author: sartre

quote: It disturbs me no more to find men base, unjust, or selfish than to see apes mischievous, wolves savage, or the vulture ravenous.
author: sartre

quote: Every human endeavor, however singular it seems, involves the whole human race.
author: sartre

quote: Thats what existence means: draining ones own self dry without the sense of thirst.
author: sartre

quote: If all I asked was not a great deal, that's my problem!
author: sartre

quote: A madman's ravings are absurd in relation to the situation in which he finds himself, but not in relation to his madness.
author: sartre

quote: The viable jewels of life remain untouched when man forgets his vocation of searching for the truth of his existence.
author: sartre

quote: Photographs are not ideas. They give us ideas.
author: sartre

quote: Smooth and smiling faces everywhere, but ruin in their eyes.
author: sartre

quote: Be quiet! Anyone can spit in my face, and call me a criminal and a prostitute. But no one has the right to judge my remorse.
author: sartre

quote: I found the human heart empty and insipid everywhere except in books.
author: sartre

quote: I think that is the big danger in keeping a diary: you exaggerate everything.
author: sartre

quote: To keep hope alive one must, in spite of all mistakes, horrors, and crimes, recognize the obvious superiority of the socialist camp.
author: sartre

quote: I have such a desire to sleep and am so much behind my sleep. A good night, one good night and all this nonsense will be swept away.
author: sartre

quote: Acting is happy agony.
author: sartre

quote: Being is. Being is in-itself. Being is what it is.
author: sartre

quote: Take [Stphane] Mallarme. I hold him to be the greatest of French poets, and I have taken some time to understand him !
author: sartre

quote: I am neither virgin nor priest enough to play with the inner life.
author: sartre

quote: To think new thoughts you have to break the bones in your head
author: sartre

quote: I needed to justify my existence, and I had made an absolute of literature. It took me thirty years to get rid of this state of mind.
author: sartre

quote: Fear? If I have gained anything by damning myself, it is that I no longer have anything to fear.
author: sartre

quote: as not-bound to life.
author: sartre

quote: One could only damage oneself through the harm one did to others. One could never get directly at oneself.
author: sartre

quote: I am not recommending "popular" literature which aims at the lowest.
author: sartre

quote: Men equally honest, equally devoted to their fatherland, are momentarily separated by different conceptions of their duty.
author: sartre

quote: Better to have beasts that let themselves be killed than men who run away.
author: sartre

quote: Render a kiss or blow
author: sartre

quote: Offer all the hatred in your heart
author: sartre

quote: No one is more hated than he who speaks the truth.
author: plato

quote: A wise man speaks because he has something to say; a fool because he has to say something.
author: plato

quote: Be kind. Every person you meet
author: plato

quote: Better to complete a small task well, than to do much imperfectly.
author: plato

quote: The right question is usually more important than the right answer.
author: plato

quote: Ignorance is the root cause of all difficulties.
author: plato

quote: I am the wisest man alive, for I know one thing, and that is that I know nothing.
author: plato

quote: Good people do not need laws to tell them to act responsibly, while bad people will find a way around the laws.
author: plato

quote: The one who learns and learns and doesn't practice is like the one who plows and plows and never plants.
author: plato

quote: The measure of a man is what he does with power.
author: plato

quote: Wisest is he who knows what he does not know.
author: plato

quote: Enjoy life. There's plenty of time to be dead. Be kind, for everyone you meet is fighting a harder battle.
author: plato

quote: Those who tell the stories rule society.
author: plato

quote: The worst of all deceptions is self-deception.
author: plato

quote: You should not honor men more than truth.
author: plato

quote: One cannot make a slave of a free person, for a free person is free even in a prison.
author: plato

quote: False words are not only evil in themselves, but they infect the soul with evil.
author: plato

quote: Poverty doesn't come because of the decrease of wealth but because of the increase of desires.
author: plato

quote: Never discourage anyone who continually makes progress, no matter how slow... even if that someone is yourself!
author: plato

quote: Every heart sings a song, incomplete, until another heart whispers back.
author: plato

quote: A true artist is someone who gives birth to a new reality.
author: plato

quote: We become what we contemplate.
author: plato

quote: He who does not desire power is fit to hold it.
author: plato

quote: The three wishes of every man: to be healthy, to be rich by honest means, and to be beautiful.
author: plato

quote: Do not train children to learning by force and harshness, but direct them to it by what amuses their minds.
author: plato

quote: He who love touches walks not in darkness.
author: plato

quote: Pleasure is the bait of sin
author: plato

quote: A good decision is based on knowledge, and not on numbers.
author: plato

quote: When man is not properly trained, he is the most savage animal on the face of the globe.
author: plato

quote: Happiness springs from doing good and helping others.
author: plato

quote: One of the penalties for refusing to participate in politics is that you end up being governed by your inferiors.
author: plato

quote: The blame is his who chooses: God is blameless.
author: plato

quote: Do not expect justice where might is right.
author: plato

quote: When you feel grateful, you become great, and eventually attract great things.
author: plato

quote: If we are to have any hope for the future, those who have lanterns must pass them on to others.
author: plato

quote: Mankind will never see an end of trouble until lovers of wisdom come to hold political power, or the holders of power become lovers of wisdom
author: plato

quote: Those who are too smart to engage in politics are punished by being governed by those who are dumber.
author: plato

quote: A dog has the soul of a philosopher.
author: plato

quote: Thinking is the soul talking to itself.
author: plato

quote: midwife to the awakening of the Soul in another person.
author: plato

quote: All wars are fought for the sake of getting money.
author: plato

quote: Rules for Happiness: something to do, someone to love, something to hope for.
author: kant

quote: Do the right thing because it is right.
author: kant

quote: The only thing permanent is change.
author: kant

quote: Give a man everything he wants and at that moment everything is not everything
author: kant

quote: Great minds think for themselves.
author: kant

quote: Perpetual Peace is only found in the graveyard.
author: kant

quote: A single line in the Bible has consoled me more than all the books I ever read besides.
author: kant

quote: All our knowledge begins with the senses, proceeds then to the understanding, and ends with reason. There is nothing higher than reason.
author: kant

quote: If justice perishes, human life on Earth has lost its meaning.
author: kant

quote: Morality is not properly the doctrine of how we may make ourselves happy, but how we may make ourselves worthy of happiness.
author: kant

quote: Out of the crooked timber of humanity, no straight thing was ever made.
author: kant

quote: Thoughts without content are empty, intuitions without concepts are blind.
author: kant

quote: Immaturity is the incapacity to use one's intelligence without the guidance of another.
author: kant

quote: The nice thing about living in a small town is that when you don't know what you're doing, someone else does.
author: kant

quote: Two things strike me dumb: the infinite starry heavens, and the sense of right and wrong in man.
author: kant

quote: Reason can never prove the existence of God.
author: kant

quote: By a lie, a man... annihilates his dignity as a man.
author: kant

quote: Religion is too important a matter to its devotees to be a subject of ridicule. If they indulge in absurdities, they are to be pitied rather than ridiculed.
author: kant

quote: [A ruler is merely] the trustee of the rights of other men and he must always stand in dread of having in some way violated these rights.
author: kant

quote: The death of dogma is the birth of morality.
author: kant

quote: Freedom is that faculty that enlarges the usefulness of all other faculties.
author: kant

quote: Philosophy stands in need of a science which shall determine the possibility, principles, and extent of human knowledge  priori.
author: kant

quote: Thrift is care and scruple in the spending of one's means. It is not a virtue and it requires neither skill nor talent.
author: kant

quote: If a man is often the subject of conversation he soon becomes the subject of criticism.
author: kant

quote: Enlightenment is man's emergence from his self-incurred immaturity.
author: kant

quote: Give me matter, and I will construct a world out of it!
author: kant

quote: Even a man's exact imitation of the song of the nightingale displeases us when we discover that it is a mimicry, and not the nightingale.
author: kant

quote: [R]eason is... given to us as a practical faculty, that is, as one that influences the will.
author: kant

quote: The business of philosophy is not to give rules, but to analyze the private judgments of common reason.
author: kant

quote: There is nothing higher than reason.
author: kant

quote: Time is not an empirical concept. For neither co-existence nor succession would be perceived by us, if the representation of time did not exist as a foundation a priori.
author: kant

quote: Have patience awhile; slanders are not long-lived. Truth is the child of time; erelong she shall appear to vindicate thee.
author: kant

quote: But only he who, himself enlightened, is not afraid of shadows.
author: kant

quote: But although all our knowledge begins with experience, it does not follow that it arises from experience.
author: kant

quote: Enlightenment is the liberation of man from his self-caused state of minority... Supere aude! Dare to use your own understanding!is thus the motto of the Enlightenment.
author: kant

quote: Standing armies shall in time be totally abolished.
author: kant

quote: Everything in nature acts in conformity with law.
author: kant

quote: Innocence is indeed a glorious thing; but, unfortunately, it does not keep very well and is easily led astray.
author: kant
